questions.question_text: An organization has expanded its operations by opening a remote office. The new office is fully furnished with office resources to support up to 50 employees working on any given day. Which of the following VPN solutions would BEST support the new office?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Site-to-site VPN provides secure connectivity between two or more geographically dispersed locations, such as a main office and a remote office. It is a good choice when multiple users need to access network resources from the remote office, as it allows all the users in the remote office to securely connect to the main office network using a single VPN connection. This solution provides a secure, encrypted tunnel between the two sites, allowing traffic to flow securely between them.

comments.content: Remote can be a physically remote location, it doesn't necessarily have to be a cloud based location.

discussion.content: How remote office can be furnished, wtf :D, remote means working from home, when all employess are in the office how we can call it remote instead of on-site?

Selected Answer: C
Yes and yes

comments.content:
A) Always on: VPN that doesn't require user interaction, you are always connected
B) Remote access: to connect to a private net over untrusted public networks
C Site-to-site: connect to local area net, ideal for business and government, specially if it has multiple offices (CORRECT ANSWER)
D) Full tunnel: route all internet traffic from the device through VPN, regardless of the source or destination

discussion.content: Can anyone explain each option ?

Selected Answer: C
A site-to-site VPN establishes a secure connection between two or more networks, typically connecting the main office with remote locations or branch offices. In this scenario, the new remote office is fully furnished with office resources, indicating a permanent or semi-permanent setup.

With a site-to-site VPN, the remote office can establish a secure connection to the main office network, allowing employees in the remote office to access resources and systems located at the main office. It provides a secure and encrypted connection between the two locations, enabling seamless and protected communication.

Selected Answer: C
Site-to-site VPNs

Site-to-site VPNs are frequently used by companies with multiple offices in different geographic locations that need to access and use the corporate network on an ongoing basis. With a site-to-site VPN, a company can securely connect its corporate network with its remote offices to communicate and share resources with them as a single network.

choices.C: A security control objective cannot be met through a technical change, so the company performs regular audits to determine if violations have occurred.
choices.A: A security control objective cannot be met through a technical change, so the company purchases insurance and is no longer concerned about losses from data breaches.
choices.D: A security control objective cannot be met through a technical change, so the Chief Information Officer decides to sign off on the risk.
choices.B: A security control objective cannot be met through a technical change, so the company implements a policy to train users on a more secure method of operation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following scenarios BEST describes a risk reduction technique?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A is transference. 
B is mitigation.
C is detection. 
D is acceptance. 
 
The only answer reducing risk is B.

comments.content:
Risk types: acceptance, avoidance, transferance, mitigation
Control types: preventive, detective, corrective, derrent, compensative, physical

According to the CompTIA guide, but the provided answer is correct B) because is mitigating (reducing) the risk by implementing a policy

discussion.content:
Just passed the exam with a score of 800 on 10/28/23. About 90% of the questions are from here.
This question is on the exam.
Why it can not be c as regular audits will also help to reduce the risk?

comments.content: It doesn't reduce the risk, the violations may have already occurred.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Going against the majority here...

A is transference.
B is avoidance.
C is detection so mitigation.
D is acceptance.

comments.content:
B. is NOT avoidance.

Nevertheless, B is a better risk reduction/mitigation technique compared to C.

B is a better risk reduction/mitigation technique compared to C, because training is a preventive control, while C. is primarily a detective and subsequently corrective control. 

Prevention is the best form of Control.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
In this scenario, the company recognizes that a technical change alone cannot effectively address the security control objective. Instead, they opt to implement a policy to train users on a more secure method of operation. By providing proper training and education to users, the company aims to reduce the risk associated with the control objective that cannot be met through technical means. This approach focuses on enhancing user awareness, knowledge, and behavior to mitigate potential security risks and improve overall security posture.

"A security control objective cannot be met through a technical change, so the company implements a policy to train users on a more secure method of operation."

Risk reduction techniques are designed to lower the probability or impact of identified risks. Option B describes a risk reduction technique through the implementation of a policy to train users on a more secure method of operation, thereby reducing the probability of security incidents caused by user error.

Selected Answer: B
B. A security control objective cannot be met through a technical change, so the company implements a policy to train users on a more secure method of operation.

Selected Answer: B
A security control objective cannot be met through a technical change, so the company implements a policy to train users on a more secure method of operation.

Selected Answer: B
considering B

questions.question_text: Which of the following social engineering attacks BEST describes an email that is primarily intended to mislead recipients into forwarding the email to others?

discussion.content:
Just passed the exam with a score of 800 on 10/28/23. About 90% of the questions are from here.
This question is on the exam.

Selected Answer: A
Sensational emails meant to be forwarded = Hoaxes

Selected Answer: A
Hoaxing involves sending false information to deceive recipients. Hoax emails are specifically designed to be forwarded, creating a viral spread of the misinformation or false alarm they contain. The attacker in this context is aiming to spread misinformation, not to harvest credentials or sensitive information as in phishing attacks.

Selected Answer: D
I never heard about "hoaxing". It is Just a mail of Phishing contain an Hoax

Selected Answer: A
Hoaxes

Selected Answer: A
Hoaxing refers to spreading false or misleading information with the intention of tricking or fooling others. In the context of an email, a hoax email typically contains a fabricated story, false warning, or misleading information designed to provoke recipients into sharing or forwarding the email to others. The aim is to create a sense of urgency or curiosity that prompts individuals to take action and spread the message further.

Selected Answer: A
Hoaxes

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is Hoaxes

Selected Answer: A
hoax : false sensational messages
Answer should be A. Hoaxing.

Selected Answer: A
A virus hoax is a false warning about a computer virus. Typically, the warning arrives in an email note or is distributed through a note in a company's internal network. These notes are usually forwarded using distribution lists, and they will typically suggest that the recipient forward the note to other distribution lists. (source:techtarget.com)

questions.question_text: Which of the following will provide the BEST physical security countermeasures to stop intruders? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: D and E are the only ones that would physically interfere with someone from intruding

Selected Answer: DE
Lighting can help provide visibility at night and deter potential intruders, but it may not necessarily stop an intruder who is determined to enter a facility. Access control vestibules, fencing, are more directly aimed at preventing entry. Alarms and signage can also serve as a deterrent and provide a way to alert security personnel if an intrusion occurs.

Selected Answer: DE
Intruders can be detected by strong lightning, alarms, and sensors. However, these measures alone don't physically prevent intruders from bypassing security. Signage may discourage intruders but doesn't physically stop them. Access control vestibules and fences can physically prevent intruders from accessing valuable assets and restricted areas.

Selected Answer: DE
Access control vestibules: Access control vestibules are enclosed spaces or rooms located at entry points that require individuals to pass through multiple layers of access control measures before gaining entry to a secured area. This can include ID verification, biometric authentication, security guards, or controlled entry systems. Access control vestibules help prevent unauthorized access by creating a controlled and monitored entry point, increasing the difficulty for intruders to breach the facility.
Fencing: Fencing is a physical barrier erected around the perimeter of a facility or specific areas to restrict unauthorized entry. Fences can be made of various materials such as metal, concrete, or wire mesh and can have additional features like barbed wire or electronic sensors. Fencing provides a clear boundary and serves as a deterrent to potential intruders, making it more challenging for them to gain unauthorized access to the premises.

Physical
– Fences, locks, mantraps – Real-world security Professor messer

keyword is STOP hence we need preventive controls. Alarm, lighting are deterrent at best, alarm and sensors can act as detective control - access control vestibules and fencing are the only preventive access controls here.

Selected Answer: DE
also selecting D+E

Selected Answer: C
Data has to be first classified for the DLP to know which data can leave the network and which can't.

Selected Answer: C
The first step the company should perform to restrict emailing of PHI (Protected Health Information) documents is Classification. In a Data Loss Prevention (DLP) solution, classification involves identifying and labeling data based on its sensitivity or classification level. In this case, the company would classify documents containing PHI as sensitive or confidential. This classification allows the DLP solution to recognize and enforce policies that restrict the emailing of such documents or prevent them from being transmitted outside the organization.

Selected Answer: C
In order to restrict emailing of PHI (Protected Health Information) documents, the first step should be to perform classification. Classification involves identifying and categorizing data based on its sensitivity and importance. By classifying documents containing PHI as sensitive or confidential, the company can implement appropriate security controls and restrictions.

Once the documents are classified, the DLP (Data Loss Prevention) solution can be configured to recognize and enforce policies specific to PHI documents. The DLP solution can monitor outgoing emails, analyze the content and attachments, and prevent the transmission of PHI documents based on the defined policies.
C. Classification. Data classification is the primary means by which data is protected based on its need for secrecy, sensitivity and confidentiality.

comments.content: This is sort of what I'm thinking. Before knowing how to stop PHI from leaving...need to know exactly what data has PHI.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Classification is the first step to determine what data contains PHI

Selected Answer: C
Data Classification: 
Category based on the value to the organization and the sensitivity of the
information if it were to be disclosed
Classification, sure... But I also think Change management, because changing any sort of business process typically starts with that.

comments.content: Change management doesn't make sense in this context, because its asking what needs to be implemented first to assist the DPL in preventing PHI from being emailed. Classification is the first thing the DLP needs to properly do it's job. Change management would be like going through the approval process to add DLP as a tool to your security framework. In this case, the question already informed us that the DLP is in place. Meaning we can assume that the change management approval process has already been completed in regards to the DLP, and any implications imposed by the DLP. You wouldn't approve the use of the DLP without also approving the classification of sensitive and proprietary information.

questions.question_text: A company wants to restrict emailing of PHI documents. The company is implementing a DLP solution. In order to restrict PHI documents, which of the following should be performed FIRST?
